original.devanagari:
तदेजति तन्नैजति तद्दूरे तद्वन्तिके ।
तदन्तरस्य सर्वस्य तदु सर्वस्यास्य बाह्यतः ॥ ५ ॥

translations.text: That moves and That moves not. That is far and That is near. That is within all this and That is also outside all this.
That One moves, and It does not move. It is far, and the same is near. It is inside all this, and It is also outside all this.

bhashya.sanskrit: तत् आत्मतत्त्वं यत्प्रकृतम् एजति चलति तदेव च नैजति स्वतो नैव चलति, स्वतः अचलमेव सत् चलतीवेत्यर्थः । किञ्च, तद्दूरे वर्षकोटिशतैरप्यविदुषामप्राप्यत्वाद्दूर इव । तदु अन्तिके समीपे अत्यन्तमेव विदुषाम् , आत्मत्वात् न केवलं दूरे, अन्तिके च । तत् अन्तः अभ्यन्तरे अस्य सर्वस्य, 'य आत्मा सर्वान्तरः' इति श्रुतेः, अस्य सर्वस्य जगतो नामरूपक्रियात्मकस्य । तत् उ सर्वस्य अस्य बाह्यतः ; व्यापित्वादाकाशवन्निरतिशयसूक्ष्मत्वादन्तः ; 'प्रज्ञानघन एव' (बृ. उ. ४ । ५ । १३) इति शासनान्निरन्तरं च ॥
keyPoints: The Self moves and does not move - seemingly contradictory but true from different perspectives
It appears to move through limiting adjuncts (upādhis) but is actually motionless in itself
It is far from the ignorant, unattainable even in hundreds of millions of years
It is extremely near to the wise, being their very Self
It is inside all this universe of name, form, and action
It is outside all this, pervading like space due to extreme subtlety
It is continuous, a mass of consciousness (prajñānaghana), as per Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad
bhashya.notes: This mantra continues the paradoxical description of Brahman from mantra 4. Śaṅkara Bhagavadpāda explains how the Self can be both moving and unmoving, far and near, inside and outside - all simultaneously. The key is understanding the distinction between the Self's essential nature (svarūpa) and its appearance through limiting conditions. The reference to 'prajñānaghana' from Bṛhadāraṇyaka emphasizes the Self as a homogeneous mass of consciousness.

centralTeaching: The Self (Ātman) transcends all dualities - it simultaneously moves and is motionless, is far yet near, is within and without all creation. These apparent contradictions are resolved by understanding that the Self is beyond all spatial and temporal limitations, being the infinite, all-pervading consciousness that is both immanent and transcendent.

coreConcepts.definition: Mass of consciousness; the Self as homogeneous, continuous consciousness without any gaps or interruptions
Inner Self of all; the Self that dwells within all beings as their essence
All-pervasiveness; the quality of pervading everything like space, being both inside and outside
Extreme subtlety; the incomparable fineness of the Self that allows it to pervade everything

relatedVerses.note: Continues the theme of paradoxical descriptions of the Self (motionless yet swift)
Describes Brahman as both within and without, moving and unmoving
Similar paradoxical description: sitting it goes far, lying it goes everywhere
Source of 'prajñānaghana' - the Self as mass of consciousness
